name: monster
content:
monster

noun
 
 
/ˈmɒnstə(r)/
 
/ˈmɑːnstər/
jump to other results
  1. ​
     
    (in stories) an imaginary creature that is very large, ugly and frightening
    • a monster with three heads
    • prehistoric monsters
    see also green-eyed monster
    Extra Examples
    • a barren wilderness inhabited by monsters
    • cheap sci-fi films with bug-eyed monsters
    • (figurative) He wanted to fight the monster of poverty.
    • (figurative) I wanted to fight these monsters: I didn't want to go on living with them.
    • (figurative) The government has created a bureaucratic monster.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • big
    • giant
    • huge
    • …
    verb + monster
    • create
    • battle
    • defeat
    • …
    monster + verb
    • attack somebody/​something
    • devour somebody/​something
    • kill somebody/​something
    • …
    See full entry
  2. ​
     
    an animal or a thing that is very large or ugly
    • Their dog's an absolute monster!
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • big
    • giant
    • huge
    • …
    verb + monster
    • create
    • battle
    • defeat
    • …
    monster + verb
    • attack somebody/​something
    • devour somebody/​something
    • kill somebody/​something
    • …
    See full entry
  3. ​
     
    a person who is very cruel and evil
    • The man is a monster; he terrifies me.
    • What sort of inhuman monster could do such a thing?
    • The tabloid papers labelled him ‘an evil sex monster’.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • big
    • giant
    • huge
    • …
    verb + monster
    • create
    • battle
    • defeat
    • …
    monster + verb
    • attack somebody/​something
    • devour somebody/​something
    • kill somebody/​something
    • …
    See full entry
  4. ​(humorous) a child who behaves badly
    5. Word Originlate Middle English: from Old French monstre, from Latin monstrum ‘portent or monster’, from monere ‘warn’.
See monster in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: monster

name: Honey Monster Puffs™
content:
Honey Monster Puffs™

noun
 
/ˌhʌni mɒnstə ˈpʌfs/
 
/ˌhʌni mɑːnstər ˈpʌfs/
[plural]
jump to other results
  1. ​a well-known breakfast food that consists of small pieces of crisp wheat covered in sugar, and is eaten with milk. Its most famous advertising character is a large furry yellow creature called the Honey Monster. Until 2014 they were called Sugar Puffs'but then the amount of sugar in them was reduced and they were given the new name Honey Monster Puffs because customers were no longer attracted by the emphasis on sugar.
Check pronunciation: Honey Monster Puffs™

name: the green-eyed monster
content:
the green-eyed monster

noun
 
/ðə ˌɡriːn aɪd ˈmɒnstə(r)/
 
/ðə ˌɡriːn aɪd ˈmɑːnstər/
(informal)
jump to other results
  1. ​used as a way of talking about being jealous (= angry or unhappy because somebody has something you wish you had or because somebody you love shows interest in somebody else)
See the green-eyed monster in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: the green-eyed monster

name: the Official Monster Raving Loony Party
content:
the Official Monster Raving Loony Party

 
/ði əˌfɪʃl ˌmɒnstə reɪvɪŋ ˈluːni pɑːti/
 
/ði əˌfɪʃl ˌmɑːnstər reɪvɪŋ ˈluːni pɑːrti/
jump to other results
  1. ​a small political party established in Britain in 1983 by David Sutch (1942-99), who was known as Screaming Lord Sutch. It has attracted a lot of publicity during elections because of its strange policies and the humorous appearance of its candidates. Before the general election of 1997 it had a candidate in every election and by-election. Its policies exist to make fun of British politics, and they provide voters with a way of protesting when they do not support any of the main political parties. Its candidates have in fact won in some local elections. The party's slogan is 'Vote for Insanity'.
Check pronunciation: the Official Monster Raving Loony Party
nearBys: the Official Monster Raving Loony Party

name: Frankenstein
content:
Frankenstein

noun
 
/ˈfræŋkənstaɪn/
 
/ˈfræŋkənstaɪn/
(also Frankenstein’s monster, Frankenstein monster)
jump to other results
  1. ​used to talk about something that somebody creates or invents that goes out of control and becomes dangerous, often destroying the person who created it
    • The organization has now become a Frankenstein monster beyond the control of the people who created it.
    • If you were going to do a Frankenstein and put a swimmer together from scratch, you would build Michael Phelps.
    • Can genetic engineering shake off its Frankenstein image?
    More Like This Expressions from literary sourcesExpressions from literary sources

    Topics Dangerc2
    Word OriginFrom the novel Frankenstein by Mary Shelley in which a scientist called Frankenstein makes a creature from pieces of dead bodies and brings it to life.
